articles.headline: SAT’s New ‘Adversity Score’ Will Take Students’ Hardships Into Account
articles.snippet: The College Board is adding a measure of students’ socioeconomic background to help colleges put test scores in context.
articles.abstract: The College Board is adding a measure of students’ socioeconomic background to help colleges put test scores in context.
articles.lead_paragraph: The College Board, the company that administers the SAT exam taken by about two million students a year, will for the first time assess students not just on their math and verbal skills, but also on their educational and socioeconomic backgrounds, entering a fraught battle over the fairness of high-stakes testing.

articles.headline: Trump Tells Pentagon Chief He Does Not Want War With Iran
articles.snippet: The president’s statement came during a briefing on the rising tensions with Tehran, and officials said he was firm in saying he did not want a military clash.
articles.abstract: The president’s statement came during a briefing on the rising tensions with Tehran, and officials said he was firm in saying he did not want a military clash.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has sought to put the brakes on a brewing confrontation with Iran in recent days, telling the acting defense secretary, Patrick Shanahan, that he does not want to go to war with Iran, administration officials said, while his senior diplomats began searching for ways to defuse the tensions.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Maggie Haberman and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: How Xi’s Last-Minute Switch on U.S.-China Trade Deal Upended It
articles.snippet: Xi Jinping miscalculated President Trump’s willingness to accept a changed deal. Now angry rhetoric could complicate efforts to return to negotiations.
articles.abstract: Xi Jinping miscalculated President Trump’s willingness to accept a changed deal. Now angry rhetoric could complicate efforts to return to negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s leader, Xi Jinping, seemed confident three weeks ago that a yearlong trade war with the United States could soon subside, handing him a potent political victory.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Can Paul Huntsman Save The Salt Lake Tribune?
articles.snippet: Life got complicated for this scion of a powerful Utah family when he became the publisher of a struggling newspaper.
articles.abstract: Life got complicated for this scion of a powerful Utah family when he became the publisher of a struggling newspaper.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Life was tranquil for Paul Huntsman, a scion of a rich and powerful Utah family, before he got into the news business.

articles.headline: As Trade War Rages, China’s Sway Over the U.S. Fades
articles.snippet: Beijing once could count on allies in business and politics to help get its way. Now many of its old allies are staying on the sidelines.
articles.abstract: Beijing once could count on allies in business and politics to help get its way. Now many of its old allies are staying on the sidelines.
articles.lead_paragraph: China usually gets its way. In Washington, on Wall Street and in corporate boardrooms, Beijing has used the country’s size and promise for decades to quell opposition and reward those who helped its rise.

articles.headline: Mayor and ‘Foreign Minister’: How Bernie Sanders Brought the Cold War to Burlington
articles.snippet: Referendums, rallies, a trip to Nicaragua — all were part of his effort to infuse left-wing activism into local politics.
articles.abstract: Referendums, rallies, a trip to Nicaragua — all were part of his effort to infuse left-wing activism into local politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — For Daniel Ortega, the president of Nicaragua, the summer of 1985 was to be a moment of extraordinary triumph. In July, on the sixth anniversary of the Sandinista revolution, Mr. Ortega would address a crowd of hundreds of thousands with a message of defiance for his political nemesis, Ronald Reagan, and the Contra militias waging war on him with support from Washington.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Luckin Coffee, Chinese Rival to Starbucks, Jumps in Its U.S. Trading Debut
articles.snippet: The successful initial public offering by the rising coffee company bucks the recent trend of weakness among tech start-ups in China.
articles.abstract: The successful initial public offering by the rising coffee company bucks the recent trend of weakness among tech start-ups in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Here’s one way to compete with Starbucks in coffee: Pay your customers.

articles.headline: Trump Lifts Metal Tariffs and Delays Auto Levies, Limiting Global Trade Fight
articles.snippet: President Trump said he would remove metal tariffs on Canada and Mexico and delay auto tariffs, stepping back from opening another front in a global trade war.
articles.abstract: President Trump said he would remove metal tariffs on Canada and Mexico and delay auto tariffs, stepping back from opening another front in a global trade war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump agreed on Friday to lift tariffs on metal imports from Mexico and Canada, removing a major irritant for two important allies that in exchange agreed to stop punishing American farmers with their own taxes on pork, cheese and milk.

articles.headline: Facebook’s A.I. Whiz Now Faces the Task of Cleaning It Up. Sometimes That Brings Him to Tears.
articles.snippet: Facebook has heralded artificial intelligence as a solution to its toxic content problems. Mike Schroepfer, its chief technology officer, says it won’t solve everything.
articles.abstract: Facebook has heralded artificial intelligence as a solution to its toxic content problems. Mike Schroepfer, its chief technology officer, says it won’t solve everything.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Mike Schroepfer, Facebook’s chief technology officer, was tearing up.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Venezuela’s Collapse Is the Worst Outside of War in Decades, Economists Say
articles.snippet: Butchers have stopped selling meat cuts in favor of offal, fat shavings and cow hooves, the only animal protein many of their customers can afford.
articles.abstract: Butchers have stopped selling meat cuts in favor of offal, fat shavings and cow hooves, the only animal protein many of their customers can afford.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARACAIBO, Venezuela — Zimbabwe’s collapse under Robert Mugabe. The fall of the Soviet Union. Cuba’s disastrous unraveling in the 1990s.
